title: Who will be elected governor of Florida in the 2018 election?
preds: I contend that Andrew Gillum (D) will prevail in the Florida Gubernatorial Election for several reasons. First, polling indicates that Gillum has an average lead over Ron DeSantis (R) by 4.4 percentage points in major polling. (https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2018/governor/fl/florida_governor_desantis_vs_gillum-6518.html) Second, Trump's approval rating in the state has fallen 20 percentage points since his inauguration (https://morningconsult.com/tracking-trump/). Trump holds only a slight favorability rating in the state, and his approval rating is on the decline. Polling out of Quinnipiac demonstrate that his approval rating may be as low as 44 percent, compared to an unfavorable rating of 54 percent. (https://poll.qu.edu/florida/release-detail?ReleaseID=2572) Third, RonDeSantis has a significant degree of controversy surrounding him. He has made statements that were deemed to be racist in debates against Gillum and has accepted the support of white supremacists. (https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2018/10/25/18022094/gillum-desantis-florida-governor-debate-racists) Lastly, young voters in Florida and others are energized to rally behind the March for Our Lives movement to elect politicians who will not take money from the NRA and will support comprehensive gun control reform (https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/22/us/politics/march-for-our-lives-gun-control.html). Thus, the candidate who aligns most with this position is Andrew Gillum.

Democrats have an advantage of  30K votes in EV and mail in. 
In 2016, that advantage was 90K.  Now, voting overall is at 75% of presidential race.   TLDR this means thats going into the general election, republicans are at a small advantage to how they were in 2016 going into the general election.  In the end, this looks like it will come down to which way did the indies break.
I think election turnout will be very strong and that benefits Democrats.  Democrats have outperformed the polls. I expect that pattern will continue.  So I'm going all in with Gillum.
Based on the FiveThirtyEight Governor Forecast

This is an incredibly tight race in Florida. The sentiment between the candidates is politically charged, divisive, and personal. However, I am estimating that Andrew Gillum will win the Florida Governor's race with a 60% margin of the votes. As recently as today an NBC poll shows Andrew Gillum winning the election. Although Florida went red in the 2016 election, I believe Ron DeSantis is too strong of Trump supporter for Florida voters. He defended Trump's policy of separating families - a very contentious stand, especially in Southern Florida. This would be the first time in nearly two decades a Democrat has held the governor's seat. As a result, Andrew Gillum has monuments support from Democrats - most recently Obama campaigned for the governor. It is for these reasons I believe​ Andrew Gillum will win the seat. https://www.cnbc.com/2018/11/04/bill-nelson-and-andrew-gillum-lead-in-florida-senate-and-governor-races-poll-says.html
https://www.predictit.org/markets/detail/3542/Which-party-will-win-the-2018-Florida-gubernatorial-race
Latest polls nail shut the coffin on my counter factual possibilities. Almost past margin of error chance for loss.
Early voting up by 30%, so a shade more likely than 538's forecast that Gillum wins.

Based on the FiveThirtyEight Governor Forecast
Shifting a few points toward Gillum given his small but persistent lead in polling.

Trying to compete for a bit of a forecasting edge on this one by forecasting slightly above conventional wisdom. 538's Lite forecast which is based on polls has this race at 83-17, and while I wouldn't normally use the polls-only forecast since it underperforms the Classic & Deluxe forecasts, I think the trend with the polling suggests Gillum is in a strong position.  My biggest reservations with the forecast are related to turnout and enthusiasm, particularly with President Trump jumping into the contest to strongly support DeSantis. On the one hand, Florida strongly disapproves of the President, with a net negative ~8%, but he did win the state in 2016 and if it's a pure turnout game, then the conservative voters seem even more likely to vote with Trump's involvement. Polls are subject to a lot of bias when considering likely voters. Without this uncertainty, I would've liked to bump my forecast closer to 90-10, but I'll hold off for now.

Gillum's campaign and message, combined with his charisma and the current environment for Democrats, seems to make this an easy victory. I'm also factoring in models and polling too. I'd have him rated higher if not for the scandals regarding gifts from lobbyists. Last minute scandals might have some sticking power given the specificity. This is really the only thing DeSantis has that appears to give him any hope of winning. His record on entitlements shouldn't give him an edge among older voters. The population now understands there are benefits to Obamacare, and DeSantis voted to repeal it. The hurricane might decrease turnout in Republican areas as well (I'm not saying this is a good thing, just that it is a factor that must be considered). Republicans control both state houses in Florida, so independents who like to split their ticket have an added incentive to vote for a Democratic governor. Trump also barely won Florida, and he hasn't expanded his base.

Gillum has consistently been favored by polls across the State.  Vocal voter base and national level endorsements by prominent Democratic political figures could secure the undecided voters edging a victory.   Gillum's connection to the peninsula and the panhandle will be a critical factor in his victory in some of the biggest cities. He will either barely lose, or win by a 5% or more lead dependent on voter turnout. DeSantis is not likely to rise or fall in popularity due to endorsement by incumbent Governor and Republicans having slight gains in voter registration over Democrats this year which is a good indicator for midterm turnout.  However, Floridians have expressed Trump-fatigue more than other states which could hurt a win for DeSantis and dissuade undecided voters.   https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/governor/florida/

I ignore polls, which are skewed to show Democrat victory regardless of the facts on the ground.  Instead, I look at what has changed.  Republicans gained 1%.   Democrats dropped .8%.   When do Republicans beat Democrats in registrations?
Parkland.  However:  Not in the media at all, atm. 
Door knockers.   Last election, I was hit with 4 sets of democrat door knockers.   Got in arguments with 2 of them.
This election so far:  None.  General impression:  Over the last several elections  2014:  Rick Scott, Charlie Crist 2.9 v 2.8
2010  Rick Scott Alex Sink 2.6 vs 2.6
2006 Charlie Crist  Jim Davis 2.5 v 2.2
2002 Jeb Bush Bill McBride 2.9 v 2.2
1998 Bush Buddy McCay 2.2 v 1.8 Democrats are talking about how Gillums win is a historic win - and in a sense they're right.  Over the last 40 years, the democrats have consistently the same kind of Democrat machine candidates.   And while the adulatory media fawned over them - it papered over a lot.  Such as Alex Sink was married to bill mcbride.  Such as they were all Tampa bay.   They never seemed to resonate with the public.  Charlie Crist - a republican that turned democrat - gathered more enthusiasm than any of them.  In this election, Gillum had three significant candidates splitting the mainstream vote.   Gwen Graham who suffered from being perceived as an entitlement candidate, Phillip Levine, climate change, and Dan Green carpetbagger.     Florida democrats were correctly tired of the same old thing - and the same old democrat machine.   But how much will the machine contribute to the victory of an outsider?   Perhaps the machine is growing irrelevant.  Electoral turnout was +.03;  27% percent of registered black voters would be 450,000 votes.  Gillum got 520K. 
This doesn't show any great movement to him as part of the primary.   I do expect democrat voters to move to him in lockstep,  and I do expect the young to vote for him.  But  - his calls for a state income tax will depress turnout amid the upper and middle class as much as his youth will attract the younger.    I think as people investigate his FBI investigation, his handling of the hurricane - (previous, not current) they will also not be inspired.  Now - for the democrats on the plus side:  300K Puerto Ricans.  Huge voting block and they will vote solidly D.  Con:  Florida's economy is doing great.  People like the job the republicans have done.  Solid government.   No significant reason for a change.
DeSantis is racist but Gillum may be too progressive for most

Ballotpedia says - The Florida gubernatorial race between Tallahassee Mayor Andrew Gillum (D) and former U.S. Rep. Ron DeSantis (R) saw several developments this week in polling and endorsements.
Three public polls were released. A St. Pete Polls survey had Gillum slightly ahead 47-45 (2.0 percentage point margin of error).
A Mason-Dixon Polling & Strategy had the two about even, at 45 percent for Gillum and 44 percent for DeSantis (3.5 percentage point margin of error).
A Strategic Research Associates poll also had the two about even at 44 percent for Gillum and 43 percent for DeSantis (3.5 percentage point margin of error).
These new polls, which were conducted in late September, showed a tighter race than earlier polls.
The race saw several major endorsements as well.
Former President Barack Obama (D) and Puerto Rico Gov. Ricardo Rosselló (D) endorsed Gillum.
DeSantis was endorsed by the Florida Police Benevolent Association (PBA), which backed now-U.S. Rep. Charlie Crist (D) over incumbent Rick Scott (R) in the 2014 gubernatorial election.

Florida is highly conservative but also a swing state in the true sense of the term, Obama won the state twice. Initial estimate.  Use of poll data from https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2018/governor/fl/florida_governor_desantis_vs_gillum-6518.html  using (MoEx2 - lead(%))/MoE but unsure of methodology to convert poll % to estimated win %.

As a former Floridian I am more than familiar with the *ahem* quirkiness of the politics there which is why state wide predictions are difficult. In general, you can break the state into 3 distinct regions (panhandle, central, south) with many more sub regions all with their own political peculiarities. That said, when you look at Scott's very narrow wins and evidence pointing to a blue wave year, I have to give the advantage to Gillum.
It'll be very close but right now independents are breaking toward Democrats so that'll push Gillum over the finish line.
DeSantis is increasingly unpopular. He's tied to Trump, which is losing him votes as the Kavanaugh nomination gets uglier.  Gillum should be able to tap into Democratic voter intensity.
